awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: When Two Worlds Collide: Examining the Influence of Academic Entrepreneurship on the Professional Obligations of Academics
awd_abstract_narration:
Academic entrepreneurship is the means by which faculty and students at universities engage in the commercialization of research and innovative ideas. By encouraging members of the academic community to participate in entrepreneurship, the university benefits in the forms of new technologies and inventions. Economic benefits are realized both for the institution and for society. While these immediate economic contributions are important, the university has an amplifying effect in education. By training students in innovation, the university can create a more innovative scientific workforce, both within and outside the walls of academe. However, this may come at a cost to the other roles that faculty play--in teaching, research, and service. Therefore, this doctoral dissertation research improvement project investigates the relationship between entrepreneurship and these other professional roles. The project examines three public universities with (respectively) low, medium, and high levels of entrepreneurship. These differing institutional contexts allows for an investigation of the role of institutional environment on entrepreneurship and education.  By examining faculty perceptions of their professional commitment to their students, this project sheds light on how faculty entrepreneurial experience shapes their classroom instruction and their educational goals aimed at their students. Furthermore, the project addresses the importance of federal funding and federal programs in legitimizing and reinforcing faculty efforts to integrate their entrepreneurial experience into their teaching and mentoring of students. This project will inform the creation of better institutional policies and practices on academic entrepreneurship that best engage faculty and students in innovative activities without compromising the core education and research missions of institutions. 
  
This dissertation project follows a qualitative research design with a phenomenological approach to interviews. The project is conducted at a public university system in California. All participating campuses follow the same institutional policies but have different institutional environments and approaches to innovation. Participating campuses are characterized by their levels of engagement in entrepreneurship, which is measured by the number of spin-off firms and the total income generated by patenting and licensing. Faculty are recruited for the project because of (1) their participation in spin-off firms, (2) their conduct of research in a STEM field, and (3) their teaching of undergraduate and graduate students. Three methods are used to collect data. First, institutional policies on faculty participation in entrepreneurial activities and policies for tenure and promotion, as well as mission statements of the university and their entrepreneurship centers, are reviewed and examined to contextualize faculty perceptions and entrepreneurial motivations in their institutional settings. Second, interviews are conducted with faculty and students to explore their experiences in entrepreneurship and their entrepreneurial motivations. Third, interviews with directors and staff at the entrepreneurship centers in each university are conducted to contextualize and triangulate faculty interviews. Although faculty interviews constitute the primary data set, conventional content analysis is performed in all student, faculty, and staff interviews. In doing so, this project aims to connect faculty entrepreneurial experience with their instructional roles and shed light on how faculty entrepreneurial engagement shapes and influences an entrepreneurship education agenda of the university.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Academic entrepreneurship refers to the technology transfer process of university research and innovation into products that can be sold in the marketplace. It is imperative for universities to participate in this entrepreneurial process so that faculty research can be utilized and generate more social and economic impact that can benefit the public. However, only 1% of the university can generate sizeable entrepreneurial outputs. Many universities are unable to keep up with their entrepreneurial investment and fail to turn research into commercializeable products. One of the challenges I find is that not many faculty members can balance their entrepreneurial practices with their research activities. There is also a lack of understanding of faculty participation in academic entrepreneurship, particularly how faculty entrepreneurial experiences influence academic work and thus impact university missions.

 

I took a comprehensive approach to uncover faculty experiences in academic entrepreneurship and investigated the interactions between faculty entrepreneurship and their conduction of research, teaching, and services. I conducted more than 50 interviews with faculty and students in the university to reveal their entrepreneurial motivations, barriers, attitudes, and challenges in navigating through both entrepreneurial processes and university policies. In addition, I also conducted 72 hours fieldwork at university entrepreneurship centers to understand the administration and decision-making process with regard to faculty engagement in academic entrepreneurship. Lastly, I observed at educational workshops and programs in the entrepreneurship centers to obtain a more holistic view of the development of academic entrepreneurship in the university. Throughout this investigation process, I also reviewed institutional documents, university patents, and statistics on 50+ university participation in entrepreneurship to contextualize faculty and student interviews. In this way, I ensured the validity of the research.

 

The findings from the research suggest that academic entrepreneurship is an indispensable part of STEM education and academic life and underscore the importance of education components in academic entrepreneurship. Specifically, I find that teaching and research are closely connected and mutually benefited in the process of faculty participation in academic entrepreneurship. Faculty who participated in entrepreneurial activities are more likely to integrate entrepreneurial experiences into their teaching and instruction and are more likely to lead student entrepreneurial projects. These faculty are also more likely to conduct applied research and serve in a consulting role outside the university. If the university is more explicit in linking academic entrepreneurship with educational missions, university faculty are more motivated to integrate their entrepreneurial experiences into their academic life and impart entrepreneurial knowledge to their students. However, if the university fails to do so, their faculty are likely to have discrepancy in maintaining their entrepreneurial activities in the academic life, which case further impact on the quality of their academic life and entrepreneurial participation. To better support faculty participation in entrepreneurship, universities need to recognize faculty entrepreneurial activities in the tenure and promotion systems, thereby legitimizing academic entrepreneurship and articulating it in the university missions. This includes setting up supporting policies and evaluation criteria for academic entrepreneurship, such as criteria for quality entrepreneurial research, and quantification of faculty impact in academic entrepreneurship. In the end, the findings also point to a number of topics for further research on entrepreneurial education and the development of the entrepreneurial university.     

 

This research has two major contribution to organizational theory in higher education. First, by uncovering faculty entrepreneurs’ experiences in balancing their dual roles under different institutional environments for entrepreneurial activities, the research sheds light on the micro-process of the institutionalization of academic entrepreneurship. Second, by identifying faculty entrepreneurial behaviors and motivations, the research extends the traditional definition of organizational life in academia and fills this gap in the literature. In addition, the findings from the research has a broad impact in education and technological spaces. Academic entrepreneurship generates social and economic benefits to the society, but more importantly, it has educational benefits to the next generation of scientists and engineers. It will be of great value for policy makers and university administrators to design a dual system in the university that allows entrepreneurial impact and educational missions so that we have more educated entrepreneurs and innovative engineers contributing in society.
